name: Hotel Room 406
description: This room has achieved peak executive comfort, the kind of space designed for people who schedule vacations like business meetings. A massive desk dominates one wall, equipped with ergonomic chair, multiple monitors, and a phone with enough lines to run a small corporation. The bed is precisely firm, the kind mattress consultants recommend to people with excellent posture and 401(k)s. Blackout curtains seal the windows with such efficiency that time becomes a social construct you can ignore. A coffee maker sophisticated enough to require training sits ready for 4 AM productivity sessions. Everything suggests someone who takes work very seriously, possibly too seriously, and brings it to hotels because separation anxiety is for relationships, not spreadsheets.

features.desk: Executive grade. The chair has more adjustments than most cars. The monitors await PowerPoint presentations about quarterly projections.
features.bed: Orthopedic firmness supporting people who sleep exactly 7.5 hours because sleep consultants said so. Pillows arranged for optimal spinal alignment.
features.darkness: Blackout curtains create a void where time doesn't exist. It could be noon or midnight. The room doesn't care. Neither should you.
features.coffee: A machine capable of seventeen different brewing methods. It probably judges you for drinking it black. You drink it black anyway.
